title: Hedging muni CEFs
text:
Many muni CEFs have distribution rates in the 4-5% range, which is not bad. I don't understand why the 10-year Treasuy note yields only 1.5%, and a WSJ article The Market Forces That Propelled a Massive Rally in Long Bonds says that big drop in bond yields has been due to hedging rather than economic fundamentals. Portfolio Visualizer says that the regression model for monthly returns of XMPT (an ETF of muni CEFs) has been, over the period Aug 2011 - Jun 2019,

XMPT = 0.76*IEF + 0.13*TLT + 0.23% (link)

The alpha becomes negative when SPY is included. As we know, bond CEFs have implicit equity exposure:

XMPT = 0.68*IEF + 0.26*TLT + 0.23*SPY - 0.08% (link)

The 0.48% annual expense ratio at the ETF level of XMPT accounts for some of the negative alpha.

To return to the main topic of the post, I am considering hedging my muni CEFs by shorting Treasury note futures (which can be done at Interactive Brokers, Schwab, and other brokers).
